questions.text: On preoperative airway examination of a patient posted for an elective Caesarean section, the following picture was seen. Which scoring system can be used here to assess the airway?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mallampati scoring directly evaluates tongue-to-pharynx visibility at the bedside, making it ideal for preoperative airway screening.
  • Mallampati classification:
    • A frequently performed test that examines the size of the tongue in relation to the oral cavity.
    • The more the tongue obstructs the view of the pharyngeal structures, the more difficult intubation may be.
  • The given patient has Mallampati class III.
  • Mnemonic PUSH: Palatal arch (Class I), Uvula (Class II), Soft palate (Class III), Hard palate (Class IV).

Explanation of other options:

  • Cormack Lehane score (Options A) and Percentage of glottic opening (POGO) (Options C) score are indices to measure the glottic view on direct laryngoscopy.
  • Wilson's risk score (Option D)
    • Combines multiple parameters of ease of laryngoscopy assessment
    • Weight, head and neck movement, jaw movement, retrognathia and buck teeth
    • And gives a score which, if <5 easy laryngoscopies, 6-7 moderate difficulty, >7 severe difficulties.

choices.text: Up to 90% of the normal FRC of 2 L following preoxygenation is filled with oxygen
A preoxygenated patient may have a 2-3 min oxygen reserve
Sepsis, pregnancy, and morbid obesity reduce the safe apneic period
Apneic oxygenation maintains arterial saturation for longer despite no ventilation

questions.text: All of the following are true about preoxygenation except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Considering the normal oxygen demand of 200 to 250 mL/min, preoxygenation actually provides an O2 reserve of about 5 - 8 minutes (up to 9 minutes in a healthy adult), not just 2 - 3 minutes.
  • Oxygen is deliveredby mask for several minutes before anaesthetic induction.
  • This preoxygenation replaces the nitrogen in FRC, with oxygen (ie, 90% of the normal FRC of 2 L is filled with oxygen) (Option A)
  • Conditions that increase oxygen demand (e.g., sepsis, pregnancy) and decrease FRC (e.g., morbid obesity, pregnancy, ascites) reduce the apneic period, ie, they desaturate at a faster rate. (Option C)
  • Apneic Oxygenation
    • Oxygen enters the blood from FRC faster than CO2 exits, creating negative alveolar pressure that draws pharyngeal O2 into the lungs.
    • With 100% O2 flow and a patent airway, arterial saturation is maintained despite no ventilation, allowing multiple airway attempts before desaturation. (Option D)

Techniques to Achieve Adequate Preoxygenation

  • Tidal-volume breathing with 100% O2 for 3 minutes (achieves ~95% nitrogen washout)
  • Vital-capacity breaths (4 maximal breaths over 30 s) can be acceptable in emergent scenarios
  • Transnasal humidified rapid-insufflation ventilatory exchange (THRIVE): 60 L/min nasal O2 for 3 min prolongs apnea time further
  • Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation (NIPPV): enhances FRC and preoxygenation in obese or respiratory-compromised patients
  • Head-up positioning: improves FRC and preoxygenation quality

questions.text: Peri-operative drug therapy involves stopping all the drugs before surgery except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thyroxine replacement is essential to maintain euthyroid status peri-operatively and should be given on the morning of surgery on an empty stomach.
  • Abrupt withdrawal risks peri-operative hypothyroidism, bradycardia, hypotension, and poor anaesthetic tolerance.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is being planned for hernia repair. He is a known smoker with a history of 20 pack years. His investigations are normal. How long should he be advised to stop smoking prior to surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Stopping smoking is thought to be beneficial preoperatively (improved mucociliary clearance, reduced sputum production, better immune function). These effects take around 6-8 weeks of abstinence to come into effect.
  • Even brief cessation (24 hours) reduces carboxyhemoglobin levels, but does not significantly reverse airway inflammation.

Adverse Effects of Smoking on Peri-operative Outcomes

  • Impaired Gas Exchange: ↑ Carboxyhemoglobin → reduced O2-carrying capacity
  • Airway Dysfunction: Chronic inflammation → mucus hypersecretion, ciliary paralysis → higher risk of atelectasis, pneumonia, bronchospasm
  • Impaired Wound Healing: Nicotine-induced vasoconstriction and carbon monoxide-mediated tissue hypoxia → delayed collagen formation
  • Cardiovascular Stress: ↑ Catecholamines → tachycardia, hypertension

Benefits of Smoking Cessation & Time Course

  • Within 12-24 Hours
    • Carboxyhemoglobin level falls toward normal
    • O2 delivery begins to improve
  • 2-3 Weeks
    • Partial restoration of ciliary function
    • Reduced airway mucus and lower risk of sputum retention
  • ≥6 Weeks
    • Near-normal mucociliary clearance
    • Improved immune function and collagen synthesis
    • Significant reduction in postoperative pulmonary and wound-healing complications

questions.text: How many hours should elapse before performing a single-shot spinal anaesthetic in a patient who is receiving 1 mg/kg enoxaparin (Lovenox) twice a day for the treatment of a deep vein thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • With high-dose enoxaparin administration (1 mg/kg twice daily), it is recommended to wait at least 24 hours after the last dose before administration of a single-shot spinal anaesthetic.
  • Enoxaparin, dalteparin, and ardeparin are low-molecular-weight heparins with a plasma half-life 2 - 4 times longer than unfractionated heparin.
  • Performing neuraxial blockade too soon after the last dose raises the risk of spinal/epidural hematoma. Always assess platelet count and coagulation profile prior to neuraxial block.
  • These drugs are commonly used for the prophylaxis of deep vein thrombosis and at high doses, for the treatment of deep vein thrombosis and as "bridge therapy" for patients chronically anticoagulated with warfarin.
  • In patients with a creatinine clearance < 30 mL/min, LMWH clearance is delayed. Extend the neuraxial interval to 36–48 hours after the last therapeutic dose.

Guideline Recommendations

  • Therapeutic LMWH (1 mg/kg BID): wait ≥ 24 h after the last dose.
  • Prophylactic LMWH (e.g., 40 mg once daily): wait ≥ 12 h before neuraxial blockade.

Explanation of other options:

6 hours (Option A) is insufficient; reflects peak effect rather than clearance.

12 hours (Option B): adequate for prophylactic dosing, not therapeutic BID dosing.

48 hours (Option D): conservative for renal failure, but unnecessary in normal clearance.

Stop both 7 to 10 days before surgery

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a bare-metal stent in the mid portion of the left anterior descending artery is scheduled for rotator cuff repair under general anaesthesia. The stent was placed 6 weeks before surgery, and the patient is on dual therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel). Which of the paradigms below would be best for managing his anticoagulation before surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Patients post-PCI (with or without stent) require dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) to prevent restenosis or thrombosis.
  • Cessation of these drugs should be reviewed with the patient's cardiologist.

Minimum Interval After Stent Placement according to stent type:

  • For elective procedures with bleeding risk:
    • ≥2 weeks delay after balloon angioplasty without stent
    • ≥6 weeks delay after a bare-metal stent
    • ≥12 months delay after a drug-eluting stent

Peri-operative Management at 6 weeks post-bare-metal stent

  • Hold clopidogrel and continue aspirin perioperatively.
  • Aspirin provides baseline inhibition of platelet aggregation and is critical to prevent acute stent thrombosis
  • Resume clopidogrel as soon as safely possible after surgery.

Emergency situations:

  • In emergencies when clopidogrel cannot be withheld, consider platelet transfusion:
    • Transfused platelets begin to function 4 hours after the last clopidogrel dose
    • Optimal function at ~24 hours post-last dose
  • Balancing bleeding risk with stent thrombosis prevention is critical in perioperative planning.
